qas.question: When was Canada's Supreme Court first established?
Canada's Supreme Court didn't actually become that country's highest court until when?
If a provincial case is appealed, how is the Supreme Court's decision applied?

answers.text: The court's decisions are final and binding

qas.question: Before 1949, Supreme Court decisions in Canada could be appealed to what body?

answers.text: the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council

plausible_answers.text: the right of appeal to the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council
appeals of decisions made by courts of appeal from the provinces and territories and appeals of decisions made by the Federal Court of Appeal

qas.question: What does the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council hear?

plausible_answers.text: for example, The Supreme Court of British Columbia does not have the final say and controversial cases heard there often get appealed in higher courts

qas.question: Why can the title "Supreme Court" be confusing?

context: In Canada, the <b4_0>Supreme Court of Canada<b4_0/> was established in <a0_0>1875<a0_0/> but only became the highest court in the country in <a1_0>1949<a1_0/> when <b5_0>the right of appeal to <a3_0>the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council<b5_0/><a3_0/> was abolished. This court hears <b6_0>appeals of decisions made by courts of appeal from the provinces and territories and appeals of decisions made by the Federal Court of Appeal<b6_0/>. <a2_0>The court's decisions are final and binding<a2_0/> on the federal courts and the courts from all provinces and territories. The title "Supreme" can be confusing because, <b7_0>for example, The Supreme Court of British Columbia does not have the final say and controversial cases heard there often get appealed in higher courts<b7_0/> - it is in fact one of the lower courts in such a process.
